licensingSteps.title: Complete 135 Hours of Pre-License Education
licensingSteps.desc: Complete three college-level courses: Real Estate Principles, Real Estate Practice, and one elective from the DRE-approved list.

licensingSteps.title: Apply for the Exam and License
licensingSteps.desc: Submit your application to the California Department of Real Estate (DRE) along with proof of completed education.

licensingSteps.title: Submit Fingerprints
licensingSteps.desc: Get fingerprinted by a Live Scan service provider using the DRE form to initiate your background check.

licensingSteps.title: Pass the State Exam
licensingSteps.desc: Schedule and pass the California real estate salesperson exam. You must score at least 70%.

licensingSteps.title: Find a Sponsoring Broker
licensingSteps.desc: To activate your license and start working, you must be hired by a licensed California real estate broker.

eligibility: Must be at least 18 years old
Must be honest and truthful (background check)
Proof of legal presence in the US
No college degree required (though pre-license courses are college-level)
educationExam: Pass California state exam (150 questions, 70% to pass)

topics: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls
Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
Practice of Real Estate and Mandated Disclosures
exam.prepTip: The California exam is known for tricky wording. Focus on vocabulary and take as many practice exams as possible.

fullTime.label: Full-time
fullTime.detail: Courses require min. 18 days each (54 days total)

faqs.q: How much does it cost to get a real estate license in California?
faqs.a: Total costs typically range from $600 to $1,150+. This includes the pre-license course ($99–$600), the state exam fee ($100), the license fee ($350), and fingerprinting costs (~$49–$75).

faqs.q: How long does it take to get a California real estate license?
faqs.a: It usually takes 3 to 6 months. California requires a minimum of 18 days per course (3 courses total), so the fastest possible time is 54 days for education, plus application processing and exam scheduling time.

faqs.q: What are the requirements for a California real estate license?
faqs.a: You must be at least 18 years old, complete 135 hours of approved education (3 college-level courses), pass the state exam with a score of 70% or higher, and pass a background check.

faqs.q: Is the California real estate exam hard?
faqs.a: Yes, it is challenging. The pass rate for first-time takers hover around 50–55%. The exam consists of 150 multiple-choice questions, and you must answer at least 105 correctly (70%) to pass.

faqs.q: Can I take the California real estate course online?
faqs.a: Yes, most students complete the 135 hours of required education online. Ensure the provider is approved by the California Department of Real Estate (DRE).

faqs.q: How much do real estate agents make in California?
faqs.a: Incomes vary widely, but the average active agent earns around $85,000 per year. Top producers in major markets like Los Angeles or San Francisco can earn well over $200,000 annually.

faqs.q: Do I need a college degree to be a real estate agent in California?
faqs.a: No, a college degree is not required. However, the three required pre-license courses (Real Estate Principles, Real Estate Practice, and an elective) are considered college-level instruction.

faqs.q: What is the best real estate school in California?
faqs.a: The best school depends on your learning style. RealEstateU offers an affordable, self-paced option, while schools like Aceable and Allied offer interactive online formats. Look for DRE-approved providers with high student ratings.

faqs.q: How do I choose between online and in-person classes?
faqs.a: Online classes offer flexibility and are usually cheaper, making them ideal for those with jobs. In-person classes provide structure and networking but are more expensive and require a set schedule.

faqs.q: Can I get a California real estate license with a criminal record?
faqs.a: It is possible, but you must be honest on your application. The DRE reviews applicants with criminal convictions on a case-by-case basis. Failure to disclose a conviction is grounds for denial.
